item.title: Tormented Souls 2 Sales Top 100,000, New Content Coming
item.content:encoded:
Developer Dual Effect and publisher PQube have announced that survival horror game Tormented Souls 2 has hit a major sales milestone just over a month after its release.

Per Gematsu, Tormented Souls 2 sales have hit 100,000 since the game launched across PC and current-gen consoles on October 23rd. That means it's reached that figure in the span of just a little over five weeks.

PQube marketing chief Andy Pearson says his company had "high hopes" for Tormented Souls 2, and that PQube has been "blown away" by the reception to the game, which has received a much-coveted Very Positive Steam rating across just under 1000 reviews since launch.

Pearson says that PQube and Dual Effect are also "working on some exciting new content", for which there will be more news "in a few weeks". Keep your eyes peeled for that if you're a Tormented Souls fan.

If you're not familiar with Tormented Souls 2, it is, as the name suggests, the sequel to 2021 survival horror throwback Tormented Souls, which was inspired by classic tank control-fixed camera-style survival horror experiences like Resident Evil and Silent Hill.

The followup once again sees you taking the role of Caroline Walker, who travels to a clinic in a remote town in order to deal with the horrifying nightmares she's been having since the events of the first game.

However, it soon becomes apparent that the clinic isn't all it's cracked up to be (after all, when are they?), and Caroline soon finds herself drawn into another survival horror adventure complete with resource management, puzzle-solving, and panicked combat against grotesque monsters.

You can check out Tormented Souls 2 right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and if you want to remind yourself about the original, you can read our review of that game right here.

item.title: Islanders Studio Coatsink Lays Off Half of Its Workforce
item.content:encoded:
Islanders studio Coatsink has announced a round of layoffs targeting around half of the workforce, which parent company Thunderful hopes will result in cost reductions of around $3 million for the year.

As revealed on the Thunderful website, about 50 to 60 Coatsink employees will be losing their jobs. Thunderful says Coatsink is "currently unable to support all existing employees", and that the layoffs are necessary to navigate a "more challenging co-development market".

Despite the hefty layoffs, Coatsink isn't closing down. Thunderful says the studio is still "a market leader in full-service co-development", and that it remains "well-positioned to deliver on all existing and upcoming top-tier projects".

These Coatsink layoffs are part of what appears to be a downward trend for parent company Thunderful; over the last couple of years, Thunderful has laid off a large number of its employees and closed down studios as a result of declining financial performance.

Thunderful's struggles did not, however, prevent Atari from purchasing a majority stake in the company in July, although that, in turn, hasn't stopped Thunderful and its subsidiaries seemingly continuing to hemorrhage employees.

As for Coatsink itself, if you're not familiar with its name, you might be familiar with some of the games it's published, including cozy city-builder Islanders and its followup New Shores, as well as laid-back angling sim Moonglow Bay and "immersive tactical VR shooter" Onward.

The studio's latest effort, Islanders: New Shores, is a followup to the original Islanders, offering much the same relaxing city-building experience as its predecessor, albeit with some new bells and whistles.

Whether or not Coatsink and Thunderful can recover from this slump remains to be seen, but sadly, the studio is far from the only one undergoing layoffs, with both big and small companies across the gaming industry letting employees go on a regular basis in recent months.

item.title: Gears Tactics Dev Splash Damage Hit by Layoffs
item.content:encoded:
Gears Tactics developer Splash Damage has announced a round of layoffs, although the exact number of staff members losing their jobs wasn't specified by the studio.

In a post on LinkedIn, Splash Damage explains its latest wave of staff cuts with the usual corporate jargon; the studio says it's letting employees go to "remain agile and adaptable in what has been a very challenging market".

The company goes on to say that it understands "this kind of change is emotionally tough", and that it will do what it can to ensure "those affected have meaningful support throughout" the layoff process. It's nothing you haven't heard before.

Splash Damage didn't give a specific reason for this round of layoffs, but since the studio hasn't released anything big since 2020's Gears Tactics, it's probably pretty easy to guess why staff members are being let go.

What's more, this isn't the first time Splash Damage has come into contact with layoffs this year. Back in January, the studio canceled its online multiplayer-focused game Transformers: Reactivate and warned that a number of roles were now "at risk of redundancy".

As far as we know, Splash Damage is still currently working on open-world survival game Project Astrid, which was announced back in 2023, although we haven't seen much of that game since its initial reveal either.

Splash Damage's most recent layoffs are part of an ongoing wave that continues to sweep the gaming industry, affecting studios both big and small. Just in the last couple of months, we've seen companies like Crystal Dynamics, Amazon Games, and Ubisoft hit by staff cuts.

As far as we know, Project Astrid, which still hasn't been fully revealed, is Splash Damage's only ongoing project at the moment. We'll have to wait and see whether the game survives what is becoming an increasingly brutal industry. Stay tuned for more.
